Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to significantly enhance the formability of thin sheet metals and the dimensional accuracy of formed features at the micrometer scale by integrating high-density electrical current with mechanical deformation through an instrumented desktop rolling mill. Two fundamental questions will be addressed in achieving the objectives: (1) how electrical current affects the plasticity and residual stress of metals subjected to deformation; and (2) how to realize in-process measurement for effective microrolling process control. The planned research tasks are: (1) Experimental characterization and constitutive modeling of material behavior subjected to mechanical and electrical loading; (2) Multi-physics modeling of mechanical stress, thermal and electro-magnetic fields in the microrolling process and mill structure; (3) In process sensing and data mapping for process characterization; and (4) System integration.

If successful, the new hybrid process will reduce process design complexity, reduce energy consumption, and reduce chemical wastes in achieving thin metal foils with desired surface finish. The new sensing methods and instrument design will push the current limits of the rolling process in terms of size, precision, cost, and energy efficiency. One of the many uses of the metal foil is micro-electrodes and contacts for the next generation of bio-implants, such as pacemakers for treating heart disorders, deep brain simulation electrodes for potentially treating Parkinson?s disease, depression, dystonia or chronic pain, and artificial pancreas for monitoring and developing new therapeutics that regulate Type 1 Diabetes. Device miniaturization enabled by microrolling will benefit patients by improving their quality of life. The collaboration between academic institutions and industry will inspire the innovations and talents needed for U.S. manufacturing companies to remain competitive. The project will provide training to graduate and undergraduate students and practitioners through research opportunities, class projects, short courses, and internships.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated the formability of thin sheet metals and the dimensional accuracy of formed features at the micrometer scale by integrating high-density electrical current with mechanical deformation through an instrumented desktop rolling mill.  A novel capacitance sensor was designed, characterized, and structurally integrated into a roll, which is part of the rolling mill, to measure variations in the forming pressure across thin sheet metals during the microrolling process when electrical current is applied to the sheet metal. The goal was to answer two fundamental questions: (1) how electrical current affects the plasticity and residual stress of metals that is subjected to deformation; and (2) how to realize in-process, real-time measurement for effective microrolling process control. 

The intellectual merit of this project comes from research performed on the following topics: (1) constitutive modeling and experimental characterization of material behavior under mechanical and electrical loading; (2) multi-physics modeling of mechanical stress, thermal and electro-magnetic fields in the microrolling process and mill structure; (3) design and modeling of process sensing and data mapping for process characterization; (4) sensor-tooling system integration. From the analytical models developed and experiments performed, it was found that the application of electrical current could have significantly different effects on the formability of different metals.  As an example, about 200% channel depth improvement in titanium was observed with the electrically-assisted mirorolling process, whereas for aluminum, improvement was only about 15%. Furthermore, it was found that electrically-assisted microrolling can be extended to bonding ultra-thin sheet metals for the production of laminated metal composites. In this project, metal sheets were bond successfully to produce Al/Al and Al/Cu sheets. Furthermore, electrically-assisted roll bonding has shown improvements in both roll force reduction and bond strength enhancement.  Through structural design optimization, improvement in sensing precision has shown to increase by over an order of magnitude. These improvement in sensing method and instrument design has pushed the limit in rolling equipment and process design towards reduction in machine size, production cost, and energy consumption, and increase in precision and quality control.  

Considering that metal foil is widely used for the production of micro-electrodes and contacts in bio-implants, such as deep brain simulation electrodes for potentially treating Parkinson’s disease, depression, dystonia or chronic pain, and artificial pancreas for monitoring and developing new therapeutics that regulate Type 1 Diabetes, this research has the broader impact by directly addressing the challenges in manufacturing process sensing and the lack of consensus as to its applicability for improving processing and quality control. The project has demonstrated both an innovative sensing platform and new analysis capability for improved closed-loop microrolling process control and enhanced quality assurance. As a result, challenging manufacturing applications can be better optimized and automated. By nature of being a GOALI project, collaboration between academic institutions and industry has been actively pursued, which has contributed to training the next generation of engineers in terms of communication for solving real-world problems beyond academic exercise only. This has the significance of enhancing the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing companies. The collaborative project provided training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students through research participation, class projects, conference presentation, and scholarly publications.  

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2017
Modified by: Robert X Gao

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This research investigated the formability of thin sheet metals and the dimensional accuracy of formed features at the micrometer scale by integrating high-density electrical current with mechanical deformation through an instrumented desktop rolling mill. A novel capacitance sensor was designed, characterized, and structurally integrated into a roll, which is part of the rolling mill, to measure variations in the forming pressure across thin sheet metals during the microrolling process when electrical current is applied to the sheet metal. The goal was to answer two fundamental questions: (1) how electrical current affects the plasticity and residual stress of metals that is subjected to deformation; and (2) how to realize in-process, real-time measurement for effective microrolling process control. The intellectual merit of this project comes from research performed on the following topics: (1) constitutive modeling and experimental characterization of material behavior under mechanical and electrical loading; (2) multi-physics modeling of mechanical stress, thermal and electro-magnetic fields in the microrolling process and mill structure; (3) design and modeling of process sensing and data mapping for process characterization; (4) sensor-tooling system integration. From the analytical models developed and experiments performed, it was found that the application of electrical current could have significantly different effects on the formability of different metals. As an example, about 200% channel depth improvement in titanium was observed with the electrically-assisted mirorolling process, whereas for aluminum, improvement was only about 15%. Furthermore, it was found that electrically-assisted microrolling can be extended to bonding ultra-thin sheet metals for the production of laminated metal composites. In this project, metal sheets were bond successfully to produce Al/Al and Al/Cu sheets. Furthermore, electrically-assisted roll bonding has shown improvements in both roll force reduction and bond strength enhancement. Through structural design optimization, improvement in sensing precision has shown to increase by over an order of magnitude. These improvement in sensing method and instrument design has pushed the limit in rolling equipment and process design towards reduction in machine size, production cost, and energy consumption, and increase in precision and quality control. Considering that metal foil is widely used for the production of micro-electrodes and contacts in bio-implants, such as deep brain simulation electrodes for potentially treating Parkinson?s disease, depression, dystonia or chronic pain, and artificial pancreas for monitoring and developing new therapeutics that regulate Type 1 Diabetes, this research has the broader impact by directly addressing the challenges in manufacturing process sensing and the lack of consensus as to its applicability for improving processing and quality control. The project has demonstrated both an innovative sensing platform and new analysis capability for improved closed-loop microrolling process control and enhanced quality assurance. As a result, challenging manufacturing applications can be better optimized and automated. By nature of being a GOALI project, collaboration between academic institutions and industry has been actively pursued, which has contributed to training the next generation of engineers in terms of communication for solving real-world problems beyond academic exercise only. This has the significance of enhancing the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing companies. The collaborative project provided training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students through research participation, class projects, conference presentation, and scholarly publications.
